publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Thus spoke to my Lady, the Knight 1Sir Arthur Acheson at whose seat it was written full of Care
Let me have your advice in a weighty affair
This Hamilton's Bawn 2A Bawn was a Place near the house inclosed with walls to keep the Cattle from being Stolen in the night whilst it sticks on my Hand
I lose by the House what I get by the Land
But how to dispose of it to the best Bidder
For a Barrack or Malthouse we now must consider
First let me suppose I make it a Malthouse
Here I have computed the Profit will fall t' us
There's Nine Hundred Pounds for labour & Grain
I increase it to twelve so Three Hundred remain
A handsome addition for Wine & good Cheer
Three Dishes a day, & three Hogsheads a year
With a Dozen large Vessels my Vault shall be stored
No little srub Ioint shall come on my Board
And you & the Dean no more shall combine,
To stint me at Night, to one Bottle of Wine
Nor Shall I for his humor permit you to purloin
A Stone & a quarter of beef from my Sirloin:
If I make it a Barrack the Crown is my TenantMy Dear I have ponderḍ again & again on't
In Poundage & Drawbacks I lose half my rent
Whatever they give me I must be Content
Or Ioin with the Court in every debate
And rather than that I would lose my Estate.
Thus ended the Knight: thus began his meek Wife
It must & it shall be a Barrack my Life
I'm grown a mere Mopus; no Company comes
But a rabble of Tenants & rusty Dull Rums3Rums a cant word in Ireland for a Country parsonfootnote on the page says country Parsons
With Parsons what Lady can keep herself clean
I'm all over daubḍ when I sit by the Dean.
But if you will give us a Barrack My Dear
The Capṭ I'm sure will always come here
I then Shall not value his Dean-ship a Straw,
For the Capṭ I warrant will keep him in awe
Or should he pretend to be brisk & alert
Will tell him that Chaplains should not be so pert
That men of his Coat should be minding their Prayerṣ
And not among Ladies to give themselves airs;
Thus argued my Lady but argued in Vain
The Knight his Opinion resolved to Maintain
But Hannah 4Hannah, my Ladys Maid who listenḍ to all that was past
And could not endure so vulgar a Taste
As soon as her Ladyship Called to be drest
Cryḍ Madam why surely My Master's Possest,
Sir Arthur the Malster! how fine it will sound!
I'd rather the Bawn were sunk under Ground
But Madm──I guessḍ there would never come good
When I saw him so often with Darby & Wood,5Darby & Wood, two of Sir Arthurs Advisers
And Now my Dreams out for I was a dream'd
That I saw a huge Rat. O! Dear how I scream'd
And after methought I had lost my new Shoes
And Molly she said I shouḍ hear some ill News
Dear Madam had you but the spirit to teaze
You might have a Barrack whenever you please
And Madam I always believed you so stout
That for Twenty Denials you would not give out
If I had a Husband like him, I purtest6Purtest protest
Till he gave me my Will I would give him no Rest
And rather than come in the same pair of Sheets
With such a cross Man I would lie in the Streets
But Mad'ṃ I beg you contrive & invent
And worry him out, till he gives his Consent
Dear Madṃ when e'er of a Barrack I think
An' I were to be hangḍ I ca'nt sleep a wink
For if a new Crotchet come into my Brain
I canṭ get it out tho' I'd never so fain.
I fancy already a Barrack Contrived
At Hamilton's Bawn & the Troop is arrived
Of this to be sure Sir Arthur has warning
And waits on the Cap't betimes in the Morning
Now see when they meet how their Honours behave
Noble Capt your Servant──Sir Arthur your Slave──
You honour me much──The honour is mine──
'Twas a sad rainy Night────but the Morning is fine──
Pray how does my Lady?────My Wife's at your Service.
I think I have seen her Picture by Iervis──Good morrow good Capt──I'll wait on you down──
You sha'nt stir a Foot──You·ll think me a Clown──
For all the World Captain──not half an inch farther──
You must be obeyḍ your Servṭ──Sir Arthur.──
My humble respects to my Lady unknown───
I hope you will use my House as your own.──
“Go: bring me my Smock, and leave of your Prate,
“Thou hast certainly gotten a Cup in thy Pate.”
Pray Madam be quiet; what was it I said?──
You had like to have put it quite out of my Head.
Next day to be sure the Captain will come
At the head of his Troop with Trumpet & Drum
Now Madam, observe how he Marches in State
The Man with the Kettle Drum enters the Gate
Dub dub a dub dub The Trumpeters follow,
Tantara, tantara, while all the Boys hollow.
See now comes the Captain all daubḍ with Gold Lace.
Oh law! the sweet Gentleman, look in his Face;
And see how he rides like a Lord of the Land.
With the fine flaming Sword that he holds in his Hand
And his Horse the dear Creter7Creter Creature it prances & rears
With Ribbons in Knots at its Tail & its Ears
At last comes the Troop by the word of command
Drawn up in our Court when the Capṭ cries, Stand──
Your Ladyship lifts up the Sash to be seen
(For sure I had dizenḍ you out like a Queen)
The Capṭ to shew he is proud of the favour,
Looks up to your Window, & Cocks up his Beaver
(His Beaver is Cockḍ: pray Madṃ mark that.
For a Captain of Horse never takes of his Hat.
Because he has never a Hand that is Idle
For the right holds the Sword & the left holds the Bridle)
Then flourishes thrice his Sword in the Air,
As a compliment due to a Lady so fair.
(How I tremble to think of the Blood it hath spilt)
Then he low'rs down the Point, & kisses the Hilt
Your Lady-ship smiles, & thus──you begin──
Pray Cap't be pleasḍ to alight & walk in;
The Capt salutes you with congee profound
And your Ladyship curtsies half way to the Ground
Kit run to your Master & bid him come to us
I'm sure he'll be proud of the honour you do us,
And Capt you'll do us the favor to Stay
And take a short Dinner here with us to·day
You're heartily welcome but as for good Cheer
You come in the very worst time of the year
If I had expected so worthy a Guest
Lord! Madam your Ladyship sure is in jest
You banter me Madm the Kingdom must grant──
You Officers Capṭ are so Complaisant
“Hist Hussy, I think I hear somebody coming──
No Madam tis only Sir Arthur a humming
To shorten my Tale for I hate a long Story
The Capt at Dinner appear?s in his Glory
The Dean & the Doctor have humbled their Pride,
For the Captainṣ entreated to sit by your Side
And because he'stheirs. Betters you carblote for him first
The Parsonṣ for envy are ready to burst.──
The Servants amazed are scarce ever able
To keep of their Eyes. as they wait at the Table;
And Molly & I have thrust in our Nose
To peep at the Captain in all his fine Clothes
Dear Madṃ be sure he's a fine spoken Man
Do but hear on the Clergy how glib his Tongue ran,
“And Madam says he if such Dinners you give
“You'll never want Parsons as long as you live
“I ne'er knew a Parson without a good Nose
“But the Devil's as welcome where ever he goes.
“G-d--me they bid us reform & repent
“But z--s by their Looks they never keep Lent:
“Mister Curate for all your grave looks I'm afraid
“You cast a Sheep's Eye on her Ladyships Maid
“I wish she would lend you her pretty white Hand
“In mending your Cassock & smoothing your Band.
(“For the Dean was so Shabby & looked like a Ninny,
“That the Capt supposed he was Curate to Ienny8Doctor Ienny a Clergyman in the Neighbourhood)
“Whenever you see a Cassock & Gown
“A hundred to one but it Covers a Clown.
“Observe how a Parson comes into a Room
“G--d--me he hobbles as bad as my Groom
“A Scholard9Scholard Scholar when just from his College broke loose
`Can hardly tell how to cry bo to a Goose.
Your 10Noveds Bluturk Omurs Ovids Plutarchs HomersNoveds & Bluturks & Omurs & Stuff
By G-d they dont signify this Pinch of Snuff.
`To give a Young Gentleman right education
`The Armys the only good School of the Nation;
“My Schoolmaster called me a Dunce & a Fool
But at Cuffs I was always the Cock of the School
“I never could take to my Book for the Blood o'me
And the Puppy Confessḍ he expected no good o'me.
“He caught me one Morning Coquetting his Wife
But he maulḍ me I ne'er was so maulḍ in my Life,
“Now Madam you'll think it a Strange thing to say
“But the sight of a Book makes me sick to this Day
Never since I was born did I hear so much Wit,
And Madam, I laughḍ till I thought I should split
So then you looked scornful and snift at the Dean,
As who should say Now am I skinny & Lean11Skinny & lean Nick-Names for my Lady
“But he durst not so much as once open his Lips
“And the Doctor was plaguily down in the Hips.
Thus merciless Hannah ran on in her Talk
Till She heard the Dean call, will your Ladyship walk?
Her Ladyship answers, I”m Iust coming down
Then turning to Hannah & forcing a Frown,
Although it was plain in her Heart she was glad
Cry'd “Hussy why sure the Wench is gone mad
How could these Chimeras get into your Brains?──
Come hither & take this old Gown for your Pains
But the Dean if this secret should come to his Ears,
Will Never have done with his Gibes, & his Ieers.
For your Life, not a Word of the matter I charge ye,
Give Me but a Barrack, a Fig for the Clergy.”866-700B
